comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: What a wonderful old paddle steamer.  It looks like she is dressed as the flagship for a regatta.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/imagegallery] It is a great ole' steamer. It was donated by the Royal Sydney Yacht Squadron, so you are right beachcomber, it is likely that it was decorated for a regatta.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 39967544@N00
comment._content: This is the coastal paddle steamer Newcastle (built 1884) that ran up the coast from Sydney to Newcastle before the Hawkesbury railway bridge and tunnels were built. She was stripped to become a hulk in 1928 and was scuttled off the coast in 1933.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/39967544@N00] Brilliant! There are several other photos and newspaper articles on Trove - search for "paddle steamer newcastle". And a model at the Powerhouse Museum with the original three funnels - from.ph/215041 .

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Aha! "P R" tricolor house flag could stand for Pittwater Regatta. The P.S. 'Newcastle' was the Flagship in 1923 and 1924 (and possibly other years). See - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16119113 trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16196217 The background scenery does look more like Pittwater than Sydney Harbour, as do some of the other photos in the series.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/39967544@N00] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Thanks all for the research! Great to be able to include more specific details. You must be right with a date in the 1920s, I believe I can spot some 1920s ladies hats on board! It really is a beautiful photograph.
